title: Liberal conservatism
text:
Liberal conservatism is a <a href="Ideology%23Political%20ideologies">political ideology</a> combining <a href="Conservatism">conservative</a> policies with <a href="Liberalism">liberal</a> stances, especially on <a href="Economic%20liberalism">economic</a> issues but also on <a href="social%20liberalism">social</a> and <a href="Ethics">ethical</a> matters, representing a brand of political conservatism strongly influenced by liberalism.
The ideology incorporates the <a href="Classical%20liberalism">classical-liberal</a> view on <a href="economic%20interventionism">economic interventionism</a>, according to which individuals should be free to participate in the <a href="Market%20%28economics%29">market</a> and <a href="Wealth%20creation">generate wealth</a> without government interference. However, liberal conservatives also hold that individuals cannot be thoroughly depended on to act responsibly in other spheres of life; therefore, they believe that a strong state is necessary to ensure <a href="law%20and%20order">law and order</a> and that <a href="institution">institution</a>s are needed to nurture a sense of duty and responsibility to the nation. They also support <a href="civil%20liberties">civil liberties</a>, along with some <a href="Social%20conservatism">socially conservative</a> positions.
In Europe, liberal conservatism is the dominant form of <a href="Conservatism%23Modern%20conservatism%20in%20different%20countries">modern conservatism</a> and <a href="centre-right%20politics">centre-right politics</a>. Most European liberal-conservative parties adhere to the <a href="European%20People%27s%20Party">European People's Party</a>, originally formed by <a href="Christian%20democracy">Christian democrats</a>.
Overview, definitions and usage.
Both "conservatism" and "liberalism" have had different meanings over time in different centuries. The term "liberal conservatism" has been used in quite different ways. It usually contrasts with <a href="Aristocracy">aristocratic</a> conservatism, which deems the principle of equality as something discordant with human nature and emphasizes instead the idea of natural inequality. As conservatives in democratic countries have embraced typical liberal institutions such as the <a href="rule%20of%20law">rule of law</a>, <a href="private%20property">private property</a>, the <a href="market%20economy">market economy</a> and <a href="constitution">constitution</a>al <a href="Representative%20democracy">representative</a> government, the liberal element of liberal conservatism became consensual among conservatives. In some countries such as the United Kingdom and the United States, the term "liberal conservatism" came to be understood simply as "conservatism" in popular culture, prompting some conservatives who embraced more strongly <a href="Classical%20liberalism">classical-liberal</a> values to call themselves "<a href="Libertarian%20conservatism">libertarians</a>" instead. However, there are differences between classical liberals and libertarians.
In the United States, conservatives often combine the economic <a href="individualism">individualism</a> of classical liberals with a <a href="Edmund%20Burke">Burkean</a> form of conservatism that emphasizes the natural inequalities between men, the irrationality of human behavior as the basis for the human drive for order and stability and the rejection of natural rights as the basis for government. From a different perspective, <a href="Conservatism%20in%20the%20United%20States">American conservatism</a> (a "hybrid of conservatism and classical liberalism") has exalted three tenets of Burkean conservatism, namely the diffidence toward the power of the state, the preference of liberty over equality and for <a href="patriotism">patriotism</a> while rejecting the three remaining tenets, namely loyalty to traditional institutions and hierarchies, scepticism regarding progress and elitism. Consequently, the term "liberal conservatism" is not used in the United States. <a href="Modern%20liberalism%20in%20the%20United%20States">Modern American liberalism</a> happens to be quite different from <a href="Liberalism%20in%20Europe">European liberalism</a> and occupies the <a href="Centre-left%20politics">centre-left</a> of the political spectrum, in contrast to many European countries where liberalism is often more associated with the <a href="Centrism">centre</a> and <a href="Centre-right%20politics">centre-right</a> while <a href="social%20democracy">social democracy</a> makes up a substantial part of the centre-left. The opposite is true in <a href="Latin%20America">Latin America</a>, where <a href="Economic%20liberalism">economically liberal</a> conservatism is often labelled under the rubric of <a href="neoliberalism">neoliberalism</a> both in popular culture and academic discourse.
In their embracement of liberal and <a href="free%20market">free market</a> principles, European liberal conservatives are clearly distinguishable from those holding <a href="National%20conservatism">national-conservative</a>, fully <a href="Social%20conservatism">socially conservative</a> and/or outright <a href="Populism">populist</a> views, let alone a <a href="Right-wing%20populism">right-wing populist</a> posture. Being liberal often involves stressing free market economics and the belief in individual responsibility together with the defense of <a href="civil%20and%20political%20rights">civil rights</a> and support for a limited <a href="welfare%20state">welfare state</a>. Compared to other centre-right political traditions such as <a href="Christian%20democracy">Christian democracy</a>, liberal conservatives are less socially conservative and more economically liberal, favouring low taxes and minimal state intervention in the economy. Some regional varieties and peculiarities can be observed:
At the European level, Christian democrats and most liberal conservatives are affiliated to the <a href="European%20People%27s%20Party">European People's Party</a> (EPP), while liberals (including conservative and social liberals) to the <a href="Alliance%20of%20Liberals%20and%20Democrats%20for%20Europe%20Party">Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party</a> (ALDE Party). In this context, some traditionally Christian-democratic parties (such as <a href="Christen-Democratisch%20en%20Vlaams">Christian-Democratic and Flemish</a> in Belgium, the <a href="Christian%20Democratic%20Appeal">Christian Democratic Appeal</a> in the Netherlands, the <a href="Christian%20Democratic%20Union%20%28Germany%29">Christian Democratic Union</a> in Germany and the <a href="Austrian%20People%27s%20Party">People's Party</a> in Austria) have become almost undistinguishable from other liberal-conservative parties. On the other hand, newer liberal-conservative parties (such as <a href="New%20Democracy%20%28Greece%29">New Democracy</a> in Greece, the <a href="Social%20Democratic%20Party%20%28Portugal%29">Social Democratic Party</a> in Portugal, the <a href="People%27s%20Party%20%28Spain%29">People's Party</a> in Spain, <a href="Forza%20Italia">Forza Italia</a>/<a href="The%20People%20of%20Freedom">The People of Freedom</a>/<a href="Forza%20Italia%20%282013%29">Forza Italia</a> in Italy, the <a href="Union%20for%20a%20Popular%20Movement">Union for a Popular Movement</a>/<a href="The%20Republicans%20%28France%29">The Republicans</a> in France and most centre-right parties from countries once belonging to the <a href="Eastern%20Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a> and <a href="Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>) have not adopted traditional labels, but their ideologies are also a mixture of conservatism, Christian democracy and liberalism.
In the modern European discourse, "liberal conservatism" usually encompasses centre-right political outlooks that reject at least to some extent social conservatism. This position is also associated with support for moderate forms of <a href="social%20safety%20net">social safety net</a> and <a href="environmentalism">environmentalism</a> (see also <a href="green%20conservatism">green conservatism</a> and <a href="green%20liberalism">green liberalism</a>). This variety of liberal conservatism has been espoused by Nordic conservatives (the <a href="Moderate%20Party">Moderate Party</a> in Sweden, the <a href="Conservative%20Party%20%28Norway%29">Conservative Party</a> in Norway and the <a href="National%20Coalition%20Party">National Coalition Party</a> in Finland) which have been fending off competition from right-wing populists to their right and do not include Christian democrats; and at times the British <a href="Conservative%20Party%20%28UK%29">Conservative Party</a>. In an interview shortly after taking office as <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Prime Minister</a> in 2010, <a href="David%20Cameron">David Cameron</a> introduced himself as a liberal conservative. During his first speech to a party conference in 2006, Cameron had defined this as believing in individual freedom and <a href="human%20rights">human rights</a>, but being skeptical of "grand schemes to remake the world".
Classical conservatism and economic liberalism.
Historically, <a href="conservatism">conservatism</a> in the 18th and 19th centuries comprised a set of principles based on concern for established <a href="tradition">tradition</a>, respect for <a href="authority">authority</a> and <a href="religious%20values">religious values</a>. This form of <a href="Traditionalist%20conservatism">traditionalist</a> or classical conservatism is often considered to be exemplified by the writings of <a href="Joseph%20de%20Maistre">Joseph de Maistre</a> in the post-<a href="Age%20of%20Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a> age. Contemporaneous <a href="liberalism">liberalism</a>, now recalled as <a href="classical%20liberalism">classical liberalism</a>, advocated both <a href="political%20freedom">political freedom</a> for individuals and a <a href="free%20market">free market</a> in the economic sphere. Ideas of this sort were promulgated by <a href="John%20Locke">John Locke</a>, <a href="Montesquieu">Montesquieu</a>, <a href="Voltaire">Voltaire</a>, <a href="Jean-Jacques%20Rousseau">Jean-Jacques Rousseau</a>, <a href="Ben%20Franklin">Ben Franklin</a>, <a href="Thomas%20Jefferson">Thomas Jefferson</a>, <a href="Thomas%20Paine">Thomas Paine</a>, <a href="Edward%20Gibbon">Edward Gibbon</a>, <a href="David%20Hume">David Hume</a>, <a href="Adam%20Smith">Adam Smith</a>, <a href="Jeremy%20Bentham">Jeremy Bentham</a> and <a href="John%20Stuart%20Mill">John Stuart Mill</a>, who are respectively remembered as the fathers of <a href="liberalism">liberalism</a>, including <a href="economic%20liberalism">economic liberalism</a>, the <a href="separation%20of%20church%20and%20state">separation of church and state</a>, <a href="social%20liberalism">social liberalism</a> and <a href="utilitarianism">utilitarianism</a>.
According to scholar Andrew Vincent, the maxim of liberal conservatism is "economics is prior to politics". Others emphasize the openness of historical change and a suspicion of tyrannical majorities behind the hailing of individual liberties and traditional virtues by authors such as <a href="Edmund%20Burke">Edmund Burke</a> and <a href="Alexis%20de%20Tocqueville">Alexis de Tocqueville</a> as the basis of current liberal conservatism which can be seen both in the works of <a href="Raymond%20Aron">Raymond Aron</a> and <a href="Michael%20Oakeshott">Michael Oakeshott</a>. However, there is general agreement that the original liberal conservatives were those who combined conservative social attitudes with an economically liberal outlook, adapting a previous aristocratic understanding of natural inequalities between men to the rule of <a href="meritocracy">meritocracy</a>, without directly criticizing privileges of birth as long as individual liberties were guaranteed. Over time, the majority of conservatives in the <a href="Western%20world">Western world</a> came to adopt free market economic ideas as the <a href="Industrial%20Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> progressed and the aristocracy lost its power, to the extent that such ideas are now generally considered as part of conservatism. Nonetheless, the term "liberal" is used in most countries to describe those with free-market economic views. This is the case in <a href="continental%20Europe">continental Europe</a>, Australia and <a href="Latin%20America">Latin America</a>.
